items.title: Sharing arguments between tasks?
items.body:
A question rather then an bug sadly.

Is there a first-class way to share CLI arguments between tasks in paver?

Something like this can be pretty annoying, as adding 20 versions of a --username flag for each function is silly. I'm considering of building a decorator to store arguments in a third party class, but this seems like it would be a killer feature to ship with paver.


The error:
```
    option -u/--username for Task: bootstrap_base_volumes is already in use
    by another task in the dependency chain.
```

items.title: doctools incompatible with Sphinx 1.7.0+
items.body:
`html` job from [doctools](paver/doctools.py) is incompatible with recent changes in Sphinx 1.7.

```
---> paver.doctools.html
mkdir_p path('docs/_build')
mkdir_p path('docs/api')
mkdir_p path('docs/_build/html')
mkdir_p path('docs/_build/doctrees')
sphinx-apidoc  -f -o docs/api myapp myapp.api
usage: paver [OPTIONS] -o <OUTPUT_PATH> <MODULE_PATH> [EXCLUDE_PATTERN, ...]
setup.py: error: the following arguments are required: -o/--output-dir
```

The paver usage is actually sphinx-apidoc usage, depending on how you call it from command line.

items.title: Paver 1.3
items.body:
With Paver 1.3, I'd like to do few major changes:
- [x] With Jython 2.7 being finally released, discontinue support for Python < 2.7 and Jython < 2.7 and get rid of the ugly hacks
- [x] Support Python 3.5

For consideration / let's see how good will it be:
- [x] Do not vendor path/six/etc anymore and use usual dependency management instead while still allowing bootstrap

items.title: virtualenv uses wrong script directory on windows
items.body:
**Reproduction**
I defined a task in _pavement.py_ in the project root directory (which is not the OS installation partition C: but the data partition D:):

```
from paver.tasks import task
from paver.virtual import virtualenv
from paver.easy import sh

@task
@virtualenv(dir="venv")
def some_task():
    # something instead of pass
    pass
```

The virtual environment has been generated using `virtualenv venv` in the project root directory before executing the task and is located in \venv.

When i execute the task on Windows 10 (64 bit) over the command promt per `paver some_task` leads to the output of the following error message:

```
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'venv\\bin\\activate_this.py'
D:\Users\Florian\Documents\GitHub\hamingja>paver tdd
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "c:\python34\lib\runpy.py", line 170, in _run_module_as_main
  "__main__", mod_spec)
File "c:\python34\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
  exec(code, run_globals)
File "C:\Python34\Scripts\paver.exe\__main__.py", line 9, in <module>
File "c:\python34\lib\site-packages\paver\tasks.py", line 878, in main
  _launch_pavement(args)
File "c:\python34\lib\site-packages\paver\tasks.py", line 858, in _launch_pavement
  _process_commands(args, auto_pending=auto_pending)
File "c:\python34\lib\site-packages\paver\tasks.py", line 809, in _process_commands
  task()
File "c:\python34\lib\site-packages\paver\tasks.py", line 317, in __call__
  with open(activate_this) as f:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'venv\\bin\\activate_this.py'
```

The **activation script is located in 'venv\Scripts\activate_this.py' on windows systems** instead of 'venv\bin\activate_this.py'.

When running the tests like described in README.txt locally on a Windows 10 (64 bit) system it seems like test `test_running_task_in_specified_virtualenv (tests_integration.test_virtualenv.TestVirtualenvTaskSpecification) ...` does never return. After waiting 5 minutes there is no output (neither "ok", nor "not ok").

**Possible bug cause**
[code passage in virtual.py, line 76 - 84](https://github.com/paver/paver/blob/master/paver/virtual.py)]

items.title: Rebuild documentation on pythonhosted.org and paver.github.io
items.body: The documentation at [pythonhosted.org](https://pythonhosted.org/Paver/) and [paver.github.io](https://paver.github.io/paver/) are outdated, and they need to be rebuilt and re-uploaded. Ideally, it would be better to use a post-commit hook on readthedocs.org and host the documentation there, instead.

    scan_module(item)
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/tasks.py", line 228, in scan_module
    scan_module(item)
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/tasks.py", line 228, in scan_module
    scan_module(item)
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/tasks.py", line 224, in scan_module
    item = getattr(module, name, None)
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/deps/six.py", line 90, in __get__
    result = self._resolve()
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/deps/six.py", line 113, in _resolve
    return _import_module(self.mod)
  File "/tmp/paver/paver/deps/six.py", line 80, in _import_module
    __import__(name)
ImportError: No module named gdbm

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 97 tests in 0.373s

FAILED (errors=3)
```

Problem was originally found when testing with Jython, which has no `gdbm` module.

Fix:

```
--- paver/tasks.py
+++ paver/tasks.py
@@ -221,7 +221,10 @@
         def scan_module(module):
             modules.add(module)
             for name in dir(module):
-                item = getattr(module, name, None)
+                try:
+                    item = getattr(module, name, None)
+                except ImportError:
+                    item = None
                 if isinstance(item, Task):
                     result.add(item)
                 if isinstance(item, types.ModuleType) and item not in modules:
```

items.title: paver breaks six
items.body:
Hi,

When trying to execute a simple attempt to import a module via the `six` module inside a `pavement.py` file, it just fails with an ImportError. To reproduce:

``` python
from paver.easy import task


@task
def foo():
    from six.moves import urllib
```

Then just run `paver foo` (with `-f <filename>` if your pavement file has a different name).

If you try to do the same import inside an `ipython` session, however, the import runs just fine, which means it's not a `six` issue, but a `paver` one.

This problem happens both in Python 2 and Python 3 environments.

items.title: Upgrade six to 1.8.0
items.body: Since 1.7, tests are failing with "Cannot import _winreg" on debian jessie.

items.title: Dependencies not installed when installing Paver project via "python setup.py install"
items.body:
Example **pavement.py** file with dependencies (_plumbum_, for example) declared via "install_requires":

``` python
from paver.setuputils import setup

setup(
name="TEST",
version="0.1",
description="TESTS",
author="Jane Doe",
author_email="none@example.net",
packages=[""],
install_requires=["plumbum"]
)
```

Generate **setup.py** and minilib:

```
$ paver generate_setup
---> paver.misctasks.generate_setup
Write setup.py
$ paver minilib
---> paver.misctasks.minilib
Generate paver-minilib.zip
```

Now try to install it in a virtualenv by invoking `python setup.py install` directly from the project directory:

```
$ mkdir test_venv
$ cd test_venv
$ virtualenv .
Running virtualenv with interpreter /usr/bin/python2
New python executable in ./bin/python2
Also creating executable in ./bin/python
Installing setuptools, pip...done.
$ . bin/activate
$ cd ..
$ python setup.py install
[ output suppressed, looks normal enough though ]
Installed /tmp/pavertest/plumbum-1.4.2-py2.7.egg
[ output suppressed ]
```

As you can see, it does declare that it installed _plumbum_. However, looking at `lib/python2.7/site-packages` inside the virtualenv directory, it isn't there. The corresponding .egg file is present in the project directory, however.

Can anyone reproduce this so far? Am I doing something wrong?

---
## Possible causes

As part of the installation, Paver's [`setuputils._dispatch_setuptools_install`](https://github.com/paver/paver/blob/c66f3183d01185ea877df1502a5aee7d34976f7b/paver/setuputils.py#L44) is called, which in turn calls setuptools' `fetch_build_eggs`.
But this seems to only download the eggs, not install them.

The requirements aren't installed by setuptools' own install command because [those people actually built a mechanism that detects where `install` was called from](https://bitbucket.org/pypa/setuptools/src/6cf39105a5b9/setuptools/command/install.py#cl-63) and does an "old-style" installtion (i.e. the way distutils does it, without installing dependencies) if it wasn't called from inside setuptools itself. I suppose that's why `_dispatch_setuptools_install` was created in the first place; it just doesn't work.

items.title: Allow overwriting of builtin tasks
items.body:
Here is a simple **pavement.py** in which the user tries to overwrite Paver's default `minilib` task:

``` python
import paver
from paver.setuputils import setup
from paver.easy import task
import paver.misctasks

setup(
name="TEST",
version="0.1",
description="TESTS",
author="John Smith",
author_email="jsmith@example.net",
packages=[""],
)

@task
def minilib():
  print("Custom minilib.")
  paver.misctasks.minilib()
```

This doesn't work, however, and the custom `minilib` function is never called when you execute `python setup.py minilib` or `paver minilib`. The string "Custom minilib" does not appear on standard output.

The code responsible for this is located at [paver/tasks.py, line 856](https://github.com/paver/paver/blob/ba025245a8742da5ca0e795388d9702e932fec04/paver/tasks.py#L856). After loading the **pavement.py** file as a module, the `help`, `minilib` and `generate_setup` builtin tasks are written to its namespace dictionary, overriding those defined in **pavement.py**.

Is there a good reason why it has to be this way? It just feels like an arbitrary limitation to me, since the documentation not only allows but encourages overwriting the tasks built into _setuptools_ and _distutils_. Why not overwrite Paver's tasks as well, then?

Pull request incoming.

items.title: shell.py missing from minilib
items.body:
In Paver 1.2.2, importing easy imports sh from shell, but the shell module is not in the default file list for minilib.  Since minilib includes easy by default, shell should be included by default as well.

As a workaround, I added the shell module manually:

``` python
options(
    minilib=Bunch(
        extra_files=['shell'],
    ),
```

It looks like the issue was introduced in aa5a16843433607d6949a7e13dfb783a329e9620.

PROCEDURE:
1. paver minilib
2. Use a "paver script" that uses "paver-minilib.zip" and execute "paver --version"

FAILS:
Because "paver/version.py" is not bundled into minilib.

REQUIRED FIX: paver/misctasc.py
Add "version" item to "filelist" variable in minilib task (line 42...).

items.title: version.py missing from minilib
items.body:
Using Paver 1.2.1 (installed with pip) 'paver minilib' includes tasks.py that imports VERSION from paver.version. The problem is version.py is not included in the zip file. From misctask.py:

``` python
filelist = ['__init__', 'defaults', 'release', 'path',
                'setuputils', "misctasks", "options", "tasks", "easy",
                'deps/__init__', 'deps/path2', 'deps/path3', 'deps/six']
filelist.extend(options.get('extra_files', []))
```

I was able to workaround this by explicitly including version in my extra_files argument in pavement.py.

``` python
options(
    minilib=Bunch(
        extra_files=['doctools', "version"]
    ),
```

The module should be included by default.

items.body:
If you execute `paver help` with "pavement.py" that uses:

``` py
# -- FILE: pavement.py
from paver.easy import *
from paver.setuputils import install_distutils_tasks

install_distutils_tasks()

Similar task categories appear multiple times (distutils.command, setuptools.command), like:

$ paver help

Tasks from distutils.command:

items.title: Paver 1.2.0 breaks the existing scripts by removing path.exists() checks from various methods
items.body: 1.2.0's commit 7783da61cbf85a749560581161b2aba1b56a4156 re-introduced the path.py module, but modified it by removing all the if self.exists() checks in methods like makedirs. This breaks existing scripts which depended on that functionality. Can we please bring those checks back to those methods?

items.title: Does not work with multiprocessing on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Call for maintainers! This milestone needs your help. Pick an issue from here and work on it in order to include it into next Paver release!

items.body:
Hi all!

Yesterday I started prototyping the use of multiprocessing in the project ( https://github.com/robotframework/RIDE ) that I'm working on.
Everything went well until I executed our application on Windows.. Suddenly I had multiple applications!?!! and executing our unit tests through paver also got me in to a situation where the testing never ends.

So how is this related to paver:
Multiprocessing has a very odd requirement that the entry point (in our case paver start script) must be safe to import when creating a new process. http://docs.python.org/library/multiprocessing.html#windows

So there must be this block in the start script:
if **name** == '**main**':
     do_the_starting()

And it seems that paver has not this in place (nor does our basic start script - this I can fix by myself).

Nosetests has a workaround for this issue: 
https://github.com/nose-devs/nose/blob/master/setup.py [starting from line 43] but I'm unsure how to implement the same thing in paver..

items.title: paver.path.path and unicode string seem to cause an exception
items.body:
Hi,

I was debugging a problem that only occurs when we start our application with paver and it seems that the bug is really in paver.

There is a paver.path.path object in sys.path and our code tries to os.path.join that with a unicode string.

so something like this fails:
os.path.join(paver.path.path('something'), u'ö')

but these work:
os.path.join(u'ö', u'ö')
os.path.join('o', u'ä')

my system specs: 64 bit ubuntu, Python 2.7.3, paver 1.1.1

items.title: Installation fails with --root option
items.body:
This is a regression in Paver 1.1.0.

items.title: Incompatibility with Jython
items.body:
Paver 1.0.5 passes all tests with Jython 2.5 and 2.7.
Paver 1.1.0 introduced incompatibility with Jython:

```
$ jython2.7 setup.py build
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 10, in <module>
    paver.tasks.main()
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/tasks.py", line 816, in main
    _launch_pavement(args)
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/tasks.py", line 816, in main
    _launch_pavement(args)
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/tasks.py", line 785, in _launch_pavement
    execfile(environment.pavement_file, mod.__dict__)
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/tasks.py", line 785, in _launch_pavement
    execfile(environment.pavement_file, mod.__dict__)
  File "pavement.py", line 1, in <module>
    from paver.easy import *
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/easy.py", line 107, in <module>
    from paver.path25 import path, pushd
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/path25.py", line 7, in <module>
    from paver.path import path
  File "/tmp/Paver-1.1.0/paver/path.py", line 93, in <module>
    if hasattr(__builtins__, 'file') and not hasattr(file, 'newlines'):
NameError: name '__builtins__' is not defined
```

`__builtins__` is a CPython-specific name of a reference to `__builtin__` module.
This patch fixes all problems:

```
--- paver/path.py
+++ paver/path.py
@@ -89,8 +89,9 @@
     basestring = (str, unicode)

 # Universal newline support
+import __builtin__
 _textmode = 'U'
-if hasattr(__builtins__, 'file') and not hasattr(file, 'newlines'):
+if hasattr(__builtin__, 'file') and not hasattr(file, 'newlines'):
     _textmode = 'r'

 class TreeWalkWarning(Warning):
```

items.title: paver -h doesn't work unless you import *
items.body:
If you have an empty pavement.py, and run paver -h, you get:

```
Build failed: Unknown task: help
```

If you have a task called help in your pavement.py, it gets executed instead of paver's help:

```
from paver.easy import *

@task
def help(): print "nope"
```

yields:

```
$ paver -h
---> pavement.help
nope
```

paver -h should not depend on any import, or on anything in the pavement.py, it should be handled directly by the paver program. 

I base this opinion on the fact that a failing paver -h (and paver --help) was an extreme source of confusion for me in attempting to learn how to use paver.

items.title: How to avoid minilib.zip
items.body:
There are some problems with minilib.zip:
 #45, #46, #49, no python3 support,..

I'm not sure why  minilib.zip is recommended by the documentation.
Most of the projects don't need anything from minilib.zip for the install task.
The only feature I use is that project info is not duplicated.
But this can be achived in other ways. For example:
I have a standard setup.py  in https://github.com/ponty/EasyProcess and 
I read it from pavement.py by this hack:

``` python
# get info from setup.py
setup_py=''.join([x for x in path('setup.py').lines() if 'setuptools' not in x])
exec(setup_py)
```

Now the package can be installed under Python3 and paver is used only for development under Python 2.7. 
This hack doesn't help projects with custom install process of course.

Maybe someone can find a better solution to avoid minilib.zip

items.title: paver ignores install_requires in setup.py
items.body:
Issue is already described over here:
https://code.google.com/p/paver/issues/detail?id=42

it's caused by this conditional in setuptools.command.install: ~70

``` python
if caller_module != 'distutils.dist' or caller_name!='run_commands':
    # We weren't called from the command line or setup(), so we
    # should run in backward-compatibility mode to support bdist_*
    # commands.
    _install.run(self)
else:
    self.do_egg_install()
```

...so when setup.py is dispatched by paver, it uses `install()` from distribute (`if` branch), which doesn't process requirements

"solved" by this hack:
https://github.com/yedpodtrzitko/paver/commit/7fe05f04195b6b4af1bf963e792fdf63a4963624

items.title: Improve consistency of path
items.body:
(Also think about upgrading to newest version)

Reported by project member dangoor, Jun 17, 2009 at http://code.google.com/p/paver/issues/detail?id=45

Juergen Hermann made some good suggestions in this thread:
http://groups.google.com/group/paver/browse_thread/thread/f806eaa4a89d6aed#

BTW, it might be a very good idea to "customize" (read: fix) it a
little more, namely in the realm of consistency and lack thereof.

What bit me lately is that it's path.basename(), but path.namebase (no
function but a property). I'd say go property all the way where a
method has property-like semantics.

You could even return a wrapped string like this...

class callable_str(str):
    def **call**(self):
        return self

and have it both ways. 

And while we're at it, what I also cannot remember for the life of me
is the semantics of "a.symlink(b)". I'd very much like to have 2
optional keyword args of the form "a.symlink(target=b)" and "a.symlink
(link=b)". Not much work and a large improvement on the rtfm-again-and-
again front.

"a.symlink(c, link|target=b)" would raise an exception, of course.

Ah yeah, and "a.utime(b)" should work, instead of the tedious "a.utime
((b.atime, b.mtime))".

It's worth noting that we need to maintain backwards compatibility and provide
DeprecationWarnings for changed behavior.

items.title: no_auto tasks will still call the auto task
minilib task fails when run from paver-minilib.zip
items.body:
# Problem

When Paver's `minilib` task runs from `paver-minilib.zip` instead of a full Paver install, it fails pretty badly, truncating the zip file and preventing subsequent runs.

This happens, in particular, `when pavement.py` extends `sdist` to run `minilib`, as in the [Getting Started](http://paver.github.com/paver/getting_started.html#hey-didn-t-you-just-create-more-work-for-me) example:

```
$ python setup.py sdist
---> pavement.sdist
---> paver.misctasks.generate_setup
Write setup.py
---> paver.misctasks.minilib
Generate paver-minilib.zip


Captured Task Output:
---------------------

---> pavement.sdist
---> paver.misctasks.generate_setup
Write setup.py
---> paver.misctasks.minilib
Generate paver-minilib.zip
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 170, in _run_task
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 166, in do_task
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 247, in __call__
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 187, in _run_task
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 167, in do_task
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/misctasks.py", line 45, in minilib
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/easy.py", line 16, in dry
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/misctasks.py", line 43, in generate_zip
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/zipfile.py", line 1031, in write
    st = os.stat(filename)
OSError: [Errno 20] Not a directory: 'paver-minilib.zip/paver/__init__.py'

$ python setup.py sdist
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 6, in <module>
    import paver.tasks
ImportError: No module named paver.tasks

$ zipinfo paver-minilib.zip 
Archive:  paver-minilib.zip
Zip file size: 22 bytes, number of entries: 0
Empty zipfile.
$
```

This is also the cause of the old Google Code [Issue 49](http://code.google.com/p/paver/issues/detail?id=49), and GitHub #3 / #13. The fix for #13 added a partial workaround for when `setup.py` can use the installed Paver instead of `paver-minilib.zip`, but the underlying problem still remains.
# Solution

I fixed two issues that prevent this from working:
1. `minilib`'s [`generate_zip`](https://github.com/paver/paver/blob/6808b6e183c62d6a923e9346d15ff3fff9dcef22/paver/misctasks.py#L37) relies on direct filesystem access to read the input files. It can use [`pkgutil.get_data`](http://docs.python.org/library/pkgutil.html#pkgutil.get_data) instead, which transparently supports Zip archives or any other import mechanism used by Python.
2. `generate_zip` truncates `paver-minilib.zip` before `get_data` has a chance to read the input files from it. This is easy to avoid by building the new Zip file in memory, and writing it to disk only once it's complete.

items.title: Tasks do not take cmdopts from their grand parents
items.body:
The following pavement.py file shows the issue. The task t3 needs t2 and t2 needs t1, but the cmdopts defined in t1 cannot be passed to t3 in a command line invocation:

```
from paver.easy import *

@task
@cmdopts(
  (("aaa=","a","Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh"),)
)
def t1(options): print "t1 "

@task
@needs('t1')
@cmdopts(
  (("bbb=","b","Bbbbbbbb"),)
)
def t2(options):
  print "t2 " + options.aaa

@task
@needs('t2')
@cmdopts(
  (("ccc=","c","CCCCCCCCC"),)
)
def t3(options):
  print "t3 " + options.aaa
```

if I run:
    $ paver help t2
    ---> paver.tasks.help

```
pavement.t2
-----------
Usage: paver pavement.t2 [options]

Options:
  -h, --help         display this help information
  -b BBB, --bbb=BBB  Bbbbbbbb
  -a AAA, --aaa=AAA  Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh
```

But the t3 task does not handle the -a option (comes from t1)

```
$ paver help t3
---> paver.tasks.help

pavement.t3
-----------
Usage: paver pavement.t3 [options]

Options:
  -h, --help         display this help information
  -c CCC, --ccc=CCC  CCCCCCCCC
  -b BBB, --bbb=BBB  Bbbbbbbb
```

If I try to run the t3 task with the -a parameter an error occurs:
    $ paver t3 -a 11111111
    Usage: paver pavement.t3 [options]

```
paver: error: no such option: -a
```

I've tested all this using the following versions:
    $ paver --version
    Paver 1.0.3

```
$ python --version
Python 2.6.6
```

I've fixed this by changing tasks.py, adding to the class Task the property needs_closure (that calculates all the tasks that are needed by a task transitively) and using it in the parser property. Here is the source code.

needs_closure property:
    @property
    def needs_closure(self):
        stack = [] + self.needs
        rv = []
        while stack:
            top = stack.pop()
            if (not top in rv):
                rv.append(top)
                needs = []
                if (environment.get_task(top)):
                    needs = environment.get_task(top).needs
                for t in needs:
                    stack.append(t)

```
    return rv
```

changes in parser property:
    # needs_tasks = [(environment.get_task(task), task) for task in self.needs]
    needs_tasks = [(environment.get_task(task), task) for task in self.needs_closure]

Can you put this fix in the official version of paver?

Thanks in advance,
Aureliano.

PS: I've sent yesterday an email to paver@googlegroups.com with this issue, but I haven't seen a response and the email did not appear in the group archives. Is it moderated?

items.title: generated sdist crashes with easy_install
items.body:
How to replicate:

1) create virtualenv
2) bin/easy_install http://download.flexget.com/unstable/FlexGet-1.0r1424.tar.gz

It will fail because easy_install will essentially run `setup.py bdist_egg` after extracting tar.gz and this seems to be same as `bdist_egg` task in pavement to my surprise.

In that task it will try to do something that does not work correctly in tar.gz context. 

Workaround I applied few months ago:

http://flexget.com/changeset?reponame=&old=1533%40trunk%2Fpavement.py&new=1531%40trunk%2Fpavement.py

I think the reason was minilib task, which was not even needed at that time.

Anyway, would be nice to get a proper fix for this. I can test if needed ...

items.title: v 1.0.3: Cannot install with python-2.{4,5} using --no-compile option
items.body:
There are error when executing the following command in Paver-1.0.3/ sources directory: 
$ python2.5 setup.py install --no-compile
running install
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 7, in 
    paver.tasks.main()
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 621, in main
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 604, in _launch_pavement
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/tasks.py", line 569, in _process_commands
  File "paver-minilib.zip/paver/setuputils.py", line 146, in __call__
  File "/usr/lib/python2.5/distutils/dist.py", line 992, in run_command
    cmd_obj = self.get_command_obj(command)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.5/distutils/dist.py", line 879, in get_command_obj
    self._set_command_options(cmd_obj, options)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.5/distutils/dist.py", line 919, in _set_command_options
    % (source, command_name, option))
distutils.errors.DistutilsOptionError: error in command line: command 'install' has no such option 'no_compile'
Same for python-2.4 and with 2.6 it works fine. With distutils-based packages this option (--no-compile) works fine. Distributions tested: Gentoo, Ubuntu 10.10 This option is used in Gentoo script (ebuild) for building/installing Paver.
